items.title: Sending Sysex as a midi message to Dexed
items.body:
Hi there, 

I am writing a Python VST host for usage in deep learning. I have successfully hosted Dexed and made some cool sounds in Python as well as extracted audio features, and now would like to leverage the sysex files obtained from the web, rather than generating my own parameters and setting them in Dexed by using juce::AudioPlugin::setParameter. 

I know sysex can be sent to a hardware DX7 via midi but I was wondering if I could wrap up the sysex files as a juce::midimessage and send them to Dexed to set the current cartrage - I am restricted in the manner I cannot use the GUI! 

Or am I thinking about this wrong?

Sorry also if this is a bad place to get in touch... 

Thanks :)

items.title: Old vs new Dexed Unique Id Value conflict
items.body:
DAW projects (I use Ableton Live) that used pre AU version of Dexed give the error message "The VST plugin could be found" since updating to newer version of Dexed. It loads perfectly otherwise. I'm assuming it's a VST unique ID issue - is there a work-around? My main concern is that I'm unable to identify which .syx patches were used. (Mac)

**EDIT**

Solved by doing the following: (Seemed to be old vs new Dexed Unique Id Value conflict)

1. Install UltraEdit (or use other XML editor)
2. Add “.zip” at end of problem “.als” file, yielding “.als.zip”
3. Open .zip file
4. Open .als file with UltraEdit
5. Find and replace ALL "1349285223" with "1147500644" (Dexed Unique Id Value)
6. Save

items.title: Loading SysEx file fails if if channel byte is not 0x00
items.body:
I have noticed that Dexed cannot load a DX7 sysex file correctly if the third byte does not equal 0x00.
The third byte in a DX7 sysex bankfile can be anything between 0x00 (channel=1) and 0x0f (channel=16). In the DX7/TX7 SysEx specification this is described as follows:

Status = 11110000
ID = 01000011
Sub Status/Ch. = 0000nnnn

Dexed fails if nnnn is anything other than 0000. This should be fixed.

Also, patchloading could be more flexible if Dexed would NOT assume a file to have a size of 4104 bytes, but instead would iterate through the values of the bytes and search for the Yamaha DX7 header bytes. From there it should test if the 4104th byte equals 0xf7. This way much more DX7 patches, including those with additional headers, DX7II files, TX7 files with performance data, would be imported correctly. Just a thought, nothing urgent: DXconvert from http://dxconvert.martintarenskeen.nl can convert almost anything (including 4-op FM synth patches) to a DX7 format that Dexed can read.

items.title: Fix for parameter values, and host parameter modulation by LFO
items.body:
Fixes not being able to dial in certain parameter values.
Also fixes way hosts (e.g. Reaper) Parameter modulation by LFO works with dexed.

bug 
-Middle C Transpose not displaying 'C5'. 

bug
-Cannot dial in certain parameter values. Float rounding error, value rounded down where it becomes int.
e.g.    Parameters that go from 0-99 skip values: 53,59
    Middle C Transpose skips value D#3

bug
- Host Reaper Parameter Modulation by LFO not modulating correctly with dexed. 
  e.g. LFO triangle shape stays on max and min value too long when modulating a dexed parameter.
  
  Lowering 'steps' values by one corrects LFO duration at max value. Rounding to nearest int corrects LFO duration on min value. Also the hosts UI, better displays the max value to be at the far right of the slider and doesn't leave extra space for one more step.
  With 'steps' reduced by one, some lines of code that were no longer needed were removed.

items.title: tweak JUCE's flags to reduce execs size and compilation time
Amplitude Modulation Depth effective range bug
items.body:
Hello,

  I noticed that the 'AMD' (Amplitude Modulation Depth) control, has a bug affecting the range of its control.  Instead of the control being effective from 0-99, only the values between 49-99 affect the amplitude modulation depth. Values from 0-49 have an amplitude modulation depth of zero.

 This bug seems related to the 'A mod sens' volume bug, in that both occur with a new instance of dexed, and both get corrected if you go to the 'PARM' window and hit 'OK', or if you touch your midi controllers modulation wheel.

example:
- open a New instance of dexed. (or reopen a project with dexed)
- hit 'INIT' to create a new sound.
- turn up 'A mod sens' on operator 1.
- turn up 'AMD' to 49.   Notice that there is unexpectedly no tremolo effect up to value 49.
- hit 'PARM' and press 'OK', Or make some movement on the modulation wheel of your midi controller.   Notice that a middle value of 49 now correctly has a noticeable tremolo, and the range of the 'AMD' control will now correctly be effective from 0-99.

Thanks.

items.title: 'A mod sens' volume bug
items.body:
Hi,

 First of all,  great app. I'm really enjoying it. Thanks for your great work on this, and everyone else involved. It's amazing how close it is to the real hardware.

 I found a bug affecting the volume. It occurs with patches that have Amplitude Modulation Sensitivity turned up.
The volume of dexed (0.9.1) can be about 8.8dB lower with those patches, whenever you open your project or open a new instance of dexed.
The volume returns to normal if you touch your midi controller keyboards modulation wheel,
or if you open the 'PARM' window and hit 'OK'.

example:
- open a new instance of dexed.
- hit 'INIT' to create a new sound.
- turn up 'A mod sens' on operator 1.
  the volume will sound rather low.
- hit 'PARM' and press 'OK',  Or  make some movement on the modulation wheel of the midi controller keyboard,  and the volume will now be about 8.8 dB louder.

thanks.

items.title: Preset loading bug
items.body:
Hi,

 I noticed a bug with loading presets from the 'CART' window, right side list.

If the patch is selected from the lower 'currently loaded cartridge' window it loads correctly.
But if the patch is selected from the 32 patches on the right hand side, then the following four parameters will not be loaded: 
wave, speed, delay, LFO key sync    (although visually on the main window it appears as if they were loaded)
Instead those four parameters already loaded from a prior patch are used.

example using the default Dexed_01 patches:
- from the 'CART' window, double click the patch 'LFORez ++Y' from the lower window of patches.
- then from the right hand list select 'SAW EM UP'
-  'SAW EM UP' patch will sound different than usual as it is using four of the parameters from the previous patch.
- now select 'SAW EM UP' from the lower window and hear the normal sound of this patch.

The right side patches should load all parameters as the lower window of patches does.

thanks.

items.title: LFO Delay bug
items.body:
Hi,  

There is a bug with the LFO Delay.
On certain delay values, once the lfo starts, it will suddenly stop, and the delay time will restart. Depending on the project sample rate and the delay value chosen, this will loop a number of times then continue normally, or loop non stop.

example:
- select INIT to create a new sound.
- turn up 'PMD'
- increase the 'LFO Delay' to one of the problem values shown below, eg. 85
  Notice the vibrato restarting.

Behaves differently depending on project sample rate.
48000 sample rate
the following delay values glitch:
74, 77, 79, 80, 82-99

44100 sample rate
the following delay values glitch:
85, 93

thanks.

Great vsti!

items.title: Cartridge data not recognised from DX7s
items.body:
I own a DX7s and when I transmit 32 voice data in block, there are obviously other SysEx messages send beforehand (e.g. microtune data), which didn´t exist in the original DX7 I believe.
Dexed 0.9.1installed as AU in Logic 10.2.2 running on 10.11.3 does not seem to receive the bulk data, also the indicator beside the MIDI-In Port in Dexed does only light up shortly while the DX7s continues to send data. The voice names in the cartridge pull-down do not change and I also cannot locate any file, that is created.
It seems the extra syses-messages are not properly ignored and prevent the reception of the voice data.
I can transmit single voice data without problem
If I remember correctly, this worked in 0.8.1.

items.title: Problem sending new sysex file to hardware DX7
items.body:
I have no problem sending cartridge-information to my DX7, but when I assemble a cartridge with existing sounds (drag and drop in the cartridge view between two different sysex files) and then save that cartridge as a new sysex, the new sysex file can not be send to my DX7. When looking at the sysex code it differs at the beginning, in what I understand as the "model ID". Instead of 09 as in the preexisting cartridge it’s now 00, perhaps this is what's causing the problem?

Code from preexisting sysex: F0 43 00 09
Code from new sysex: F0 43 00 00

items.title: Diagonal modulation paths missing from algorithm diagrams

Looks like diagonal modulation paths are missing from DEXED's algorithm diagram display.

Hey there,

I use Fedora and i tried to compile dexed so i can try it out but i must say it is big pain to do and in the end i failed.

Some packages i had to: sudo dnf install libXcursor-devel libXinerama-devel freetype-devel libX11-devel alsa-lib-devel

But in the end i got stuck on this:
 #include <public.sdk/source/vst2.x/audioeffectx.h>

It asks for something that is forbidden in free software community, the proprietary vst2.x libraries.

Could someone just build .so libraries for us, the linux users or help me to figure out this barrier?

items.title: Some patches not sounding correct until clicking off them and back on them
items.body:
Obscure set-up, so probably the set-up rather than Dexed, but thought I'd flag as it's only sporadic so could indicate a bug somewhere...
Running Dexed 0.9 on Logic 5.5.1 PC, using Chainer as a VST host - Dexed runs like a dream except when loading a song, some sounds play incorrectly until changed to another patch and then back.
Eg. If patch 4 is selected on a track and sounds strange, selecting patch 5 and then patch 4 again will cure the problem and the patch will sound correctly.

items.title: Pitch EG graph is misleading compared to actual functionality
items.body:
The actual graph according to the DX7 manual is default at a level of 50.

Ideally, this graph would have a center line going through 50 and base the graph off that.

Simple mockup below of what the actual functionality should look like.
![pegexample](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14251674/9832947/a5b39aac-594c-11e5-8bb5-61f583050856.png)

Reference page 17 of the english manual to get more confirmation.

items.title: "Send current program to DX7" Does not send pitch EG data.
items.body:
When sending the current patch to the DX7, the Pitch EG data (levels and rates) is not transmitted.

It does send correctly if the entire patch bank is submitted.

I don't know if this is something that is impossible to do or a bug, just listing it as a known issue.

items.title: Feature Request: Drag and Drop sysex file to Cartdrige
items.body: I know that I should put my sysex files on a specific folder, but it would be nice import the sysex with drag and drop directy from Finder or Windows Explorer :)

items.title: CartManager draws a black frame (shadow) on desktop when visible
items.body:
At least on Linux when dexed cart-manager is visible there's a black frame/shadow on the desktop.

This seems to be because you use a top-level window for cartmanager but add it as a child component of the plugin UI.
Turning the CartManager class into a simple Component makes the shadow go away.

See https://github.com/DISTRHO/DISTRHO-Ports/commit/53458838505efef91ed069d0a7d970b6b3588eba for a fix.

items.title: Level scaling 'L/R curve' menus display only once
items.body:
This has been reported to me a few days ago, at https://github.com/DISTRHO/DISTRHO-Ports/issues/8
I don't know if it's a linux specific bug or not.

In any case I fixed it by calling the menu async. I based my code on the juce ComboBox showPopup.
(See the bug report for a fix)

items.title: UI size is off after closing param dialog
items.body:
The setSize arguments on the PluginEditor constructor vs after closing param dialog are different.
I think you updated the code in one place and forgot to change where it was duplicated.

See https://github.com/DISTRHO/DISTRHO-Ports/commit/81cfcae381841917863ace9ddeeaacc98b0bdf77 for possible fix.

items.title: Store configs in the dll's directory
items.body:
I think it could be very useful for some people like me. I changed PluginData.cpp (lines 433 - 435) to this

``` C
#elif JUCE_WINDOWS
    if ( File::getSpecialLocation(File::currentExecutableFile).getSiblingFile("Dexed_data").isDirectory() )
        dexedAppDir = File::getSpecialLocation(File::currentExecutableFile).getSiblingFile("Dexed_data");
    else
        dexedAppDir = File::getSpecialLocation(File::userApplicationDataDirectory).getChildFile("DigitalSuburban").getChildFile("Dexed");
#else
```

and it worked. I mean if user manually creates the "Dexed_data" folder in the dll's dir then plugin will use it instead of system App's Data folder.

What do you think?

BTW it looks like you forgot to initialize `showKeyboard` so the keyboard randomly on/off if no config file is found. (Your checking `if ( prop.containsKey( String("showKeyboard") ) )` doesn't allow JUCE to use default zero value.)

Edit:
use `currentExecutableFile` everywhere for consistency (accidentally left `currentApplicationFile` in the code after testing, although they are the same for Win).

items.title: Dexed 0.9.0 fixed frequency displayed value is wrong
items.body:
I know the frequency Ratio display was fixed previously, but it seems the frequency Fixed display also needs correcting.  For instance, Coarse = 2, Fine = 34, produces 218.78 Hz according to osc_freq() in dx7note.cc, but the frequency displayed is 440 Hz in OperatorEditor::updateDisplay().

It appears to be the display that is wrong as listening to a 440 Hz fixed tone in Dexed, and comparing it to a known 440 Hz tone, they are clearly different.

items.title: TX802 patch compatibility
items.body:
I am trying to use Dexed with a [DX7 200K patch collection](http://korgpatches.com/patches/kronos/dx7_200k_collection).

However, patches for TX802 are not loaded properly (strange patch names, no sound or erroneous sounds). I though TX802 are compatible with DX7 patches. I am planning to used Dexed together with my hardware TX802.

BTW. you can target also 10.6.8 if compiling on more recent OSX xcode versions by placing the old OSX 10.6.8 sdk to the appropriate directory (taking from the old xcode version).

items.body: It will be easier to know to which key you've actually set those breakpoints then! :)

items.title: Adjusting parameters via mousewheel not sensitive enough
items.body: Seems that mousewheel adjusts parameters in steps of 3... Would be much better if it adjusted all parameters in steps of one, perhaps with an additional keyboard modifier (Ctrl?) to adjust parameters in steps of 10?

items.title: wishlist: read/write raw dx7-patches (128 bytes)
items.body: With Hexter I build up a directory with my favourite sounds. They are single sound files, raw, 128 bytes long. I would be very happy if I could load and write them with Dexed.

items.title: Anyone tried compiling dexed for AudioUnits?
items.body:
I tried compiling dexed (AudioUnits only) for 64bit binary with XCode 6.1 running on Yosemite.

I modified the following lines in JuceLibraryCode/AppConfig.h to
# define JucePlugin_Build_VST              0
# define JucePlugin_Build_AU               1

But I get Parse Issue Unknown type name 'Point' in Finder.h as well as in Quickdraw.h.
I also tried with the latest juce library (I also had to install AudioUnits header) and I could go only up to where I got loads of "Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64". 

Is there anyone that got the same problem?

items.title: Anyone tried compiling dexed for Audio
Plugin doesn't set VST unique ID
items.body: I noticed that Dexed seems to share the same plugin ID as another JUCE-based VST, so I guess you both forgot to actually set a unique ID for the plugin.

items.title: Plugin shouldn't report that silcence doesn't need to be processed.
items.body: Dexed seems to specify that the host doesn't need to process the plugin if only silence is fed into it (effFlagsNoSoundInStop in the VST SDK, in JUCE it's something like JucePlugin_SilenceInProducesSilenceOut, I think). This is wrong for a VSTi, since it should output sound even when it's being fed with silence. Dexed is the first plugin I've actually come across that sets this flag, so it triggered my host's experimental plugin suspension code (most hosts don't implement this flag, I think). Everything would have been fine if the plugin didn't have any inputs (since then it would ignore the flag), but since the plugin claims to have a stereo input, the code is still triggered. So I'd suggest to first off remove the flag and maybe also remove the input channels if they are not required.

items.title: x64 version closes FL Studio when the "load" button is pressed in Dexed
items.body: Just as the above says. Should I not have both the x64 and x32 ones together in the same folder?

items.title: FL Studio: Presets resetting to first default continuously
items.body: I can access all the preset names but they all reset to the first default preset when selected.

items.title: Support for Linux
items.body:
Hi Pascal, I tried to use the Windows VST on Linux but Wine kept crashing. So now I built a native version on Linux (on KXstudio / Ubuntu). in order to do this I created a Linux config in Introjucer. I also installed the following Juce requirements: http://www.juce.com/forum/topic/list-juce-dependancies-under-ubuntu-linux I verified that the Juce demo app can be compiled. --- here is the list of manual changes I needed to do: - change the libx11 location in the Makefile (could do this in Introjucer but I believe this is Linux version dependent) - SInt16 error / size_t error: added the following lines to synth.h (maybe you can add this to one of your own files?):
#include <stddef.h>
typedef int16_t SInt16;
- NotificationType error: removed "NotificationType::" from the following files:
PluginParam.cpp
PluginEditor.cpp
OperatorEditor.cpp
--- resulting Dexed.o Release version works great in Claudia / Carla! gruss, Markus

items.title: 64-bit and VS2013 support on Juce level
items.body:
Hi Pascal,

would you mind adding the VS 64-bit configurations and also VS 2013 target support directly on the Dexed.jucer level?

I downloaded and compiled Introjucer now and understand the structure of the project better. instead of hacking the VS 2012 vxproj file every time for the VS 2013 tools version (v110 vs. v120), I could then just export the VS 2013 build files via Introjucer.

gruss,
Markus

items.title: Get/Set VST Chunk to Recall Last Loaded Patches
items.body:
Hi Pascal,

would it be possible to set and get the 32 currently loaded patches from the VST chunk?

I believe this should be possible in the way you load the binary SYX block when starting. Basically you save the block into the VST chunk when unloading the plugin and recall it back when loading the plugin the next time. If you do not find a VST chunk, you fall back to the current solution. When the user imports a SYX file during a session, that block is saved and recalled.

That way, I can have different projects with different patch banks loaded. This is useful when you use a headless system were you can only use program changes to switch patches and not load new banks on the fly.

http://www.juce.com/api/classVSTPluginFormat.html#a666e9aa327d8daaafa05b6b899166ff9

gruss,
Markus

items.title: Sysex import leads to corrupted patches
items.body:
Hi Pascal,

thank you very much for your great work with this project! I am very excited to by able to use the Android sound engine as a VST plugin :-)

My only problem at the moment is that whenever I load a SYX file, I get corrupted patches. Sometimes the first 10 patches are okay, sometimes all are corrupted. You can see that the names are not displayed correctly in the drop-down list. Also when you load and play a corrupted patch, the plugin frequently crashes.

My environment: Windows 7 64 bit using Reaper (x64) with VST bridge. 

Notes: Happens with both your latest binary version and your latest code compiled with VS 2013. Your default patches loaded at start-up work fine, looks like they are loaded from a binary chunk instead of the SYX file, though.

Can you reproduce this on your side?

gruss,
Markus
